lines.content: MeeBot is a personal task management application that helps users keep track of their tasks. The project was developed as part of the TIC2002 Introduction to Software Engineering module, with the aim of applying sound software design principles.
MeeBot helps users manage three main types of tasks - Todo, Deadline, and Event with support for recurring schedules.

Users can add, list, mark, delete, search, filter, and sort tasks, all from a simple interface. The application supports both text commands and GUI controls, and all data is saved automatically to a JSON file.
MeeBot can be launched in two modes:
If no arguments are provided, MeeBot launches in GUI mode by default.
When MeeBot runs for the first time:
- A `.meebot` folder is created in your user directory.
- Inside it, a `data/` subfolder is created, containing `tasks.json` where your tasks are stored.
- Your tasks persist between sessions as long as `tasks.json` remains present.
**Important:** If `data/tasks.json` is missing or deleted, previously saved tasks are **not** reloaded (they are effectively lost!). A new, empty `tasks.json` will be created on the next run.
In subsequent runs, MeeBot may also create a `logs/` subfolder inside `.meebot`:
- `logs/task_load_errors.log` records tasks that failed to load to help diagnose issues.
- You can delete them if not needed; MeeBot will recreate logs when required.
| Add Todo | `todo <description>` | `todo water plants` | Adds a simple todo. |
| Add Deadline | `deadline <desc> /by <date-time>` | `deadline pay bills /by 1/11/2025 2359` | Time optional (e.g., `1/11/2025`). |
| Add Event | `event <desc> /from <date-time> /to <date-time>` | `event yoga /from 1/11/2025 1000 /to 1/11/2025 1100` | Start/end can include time or just date. |
| Mark   | `mark <index>` | `mark 1` | Use `list` to see task indices. |
| Search | `search <kw1> <kw2> ...` | `search yoga plants` | OR-match across description. |
| Filter | `filter task:<type> & done:<true\|false> & date:<DD/MM/YYYY>` | `filter task:deadline & done:false & date:1/11/2025` | Use 1‚Äì3 conditions. Types: `todo`, `deadline`, `event`. |
| Sort | `sort /by <date \| status>` | `sort /by date` | Date: earliest first; Status: pending first. Stable sort. |
MeeBot accepts natural language and standard formats for dates/times (works with `/by`, `/from`, `/to`).
- Natural language: today, tomorrow, this friday, next wednesday, in X days, end of this month, first monday of next month
deadline file claims /by end of this month
event hackathon /from next monday 10am /to next tuesday 12pm
| Issue| Likely Cause | How to Fix |

| `Unrecognized command` | Typo or wrong syntax | Use correct forms: `todo <desc>`, `deadline <desc> /by <date-time>`, `event <desc> /from <start> /to <end>`. **Tip:** type the command keyword (e.g., deadline) or help to see syntax and examples. |
| `Invalid repeat interval or count` | Wrong repeat syntax | Use `/repeat <daily, weekly, monthly, yearly> <count>`, e.g., `/repeat monthly 12`. |
| `Could not parse date/time` | Unsupported or ambiguous date phrase | Use supported formats: see above section. |
| `Start must be before end` | `/from` is not earlier than `/to`    | Ensure start < end (both date and time), e.g., `/from next monday 10am /to next monday 12pm`. |
| `No task found` | Index outside current list range | Run `list` to see indices, then use a valid number. |
| Some tasks missing after restart | One or more entries failed to load | Check `~/.meebot/logs/task_load_errors.log`. Fix malformed lines; valid tasks still load. |

| All tasks gone after restart | `data/tasks.json` missing or deleted | Verify file exists: macOS/Linux `~/.meebot/data/tasks.json`, Windows `%USERPROFILE%\.meebot\data\tasks.json`. If missing, data is lost; a new file will be created. |
| Cannot save tasks (`Access denied`) | Folder permissions issue | Ensure write access to `~/.meebot/`. |
| GUI fails to start (JavaFX error) | Environment/JavaFX setup problem | Test CLI: `./gradlew run --args="cli"`. Ensure Java 17+. |
- Teaching staff for guidance and feedback.
- Interface icons: [Flaticon by Freepik](https://www.flaticon.com/uicons/interface-icons) (used with attribution per Flaticon terms).

* Immutable record providing centralized command documentation and help text.
* This record serves as a single source of truth for all user-facing command
* documentation, including summary descriptions and detailed usage instructions.

*
  • Summary: Brief one-line descriptions for command overview
* Returns a brief summary description for the specified command type.
* Summaries are designed for display in command overview or quick reference
* scenarios where space is limited. Each summary is a concise phrase describing
* @param type the command type to get summary for
* @return brief description string, or empty string if type is null or unsupported
case SORT -> "Display tasks in sorted order";
case DELETE -> "Delete a task by number";
case MARK -> "Mark a task as done";
case UNMARK -> "Mark a task as pending";
* Returns detailed usage instructions for the specified command type.
* Details include command format specifications, parameter descriptions,
* usage examples, and any important notes or constraints. This information
* is designed for display when users request specific help for a command.
* @param type the command type to get detailed help for
* @return comprehensive usage instructions, or empty string if type is unsupported
‚è≥ To add a task with due date, with [OPTIONAL] time and repeat.
üìÖ To add an event with start and end date, with [OPTIONAL] time and repeat.
üóëÔ∏è To delete a task, type 'list' to see your tasks, then use the number.
‚ö†Ô∏è Note: Task cannot be recovered once deleted.
‚úÖ To mark a task as completed.
‚≠ï To mark a task as not completed.
üîç To find tasks whose description contains one or more keywords.
üóÇÔ∏è Sort by status: pending tasks first
üîé To filter tasks ‚Äî pick 1 to 3 conditions.
* Extracts only the "Format:" line from a command's detailed help.
* Used by GUI to display inline syntax hints in the chat bar.
* @return the format string (without the word "Format:"), or empty if none found
* Immutable message record containing error information for display to users.
* This record encapsulates error messages with contextual, user-friendly text
* that follows MeeBot's Singaporean's conversational tone and is descriptive enough
* to help users understand what went wrong and how to correct their input.
public record ErrorMessage(String message) implements Message {
Sorry, I'm mee-xed up by '%s'. I can help with:
todo, deadline, event, list, (un)mark, delete, filter, sort.
Type the command keywords (e.g. sort) for details.
Eh friend, '%s' is not a number lah. Numbers are whole numbers like 1, 2, 3.
Your command is messier than mee goreng!
%s Pick at least 1 from these 3 criteria:
Your task list is emptier than kopitiam during circuit breaker. \
Add a task before using this command!
Type 'list' to see what's actually in your task list lah!
Task is already %s, no point doing it again what!
Type 'list' to see what's actually in your task list lah!
Your date/time more fictional than Korean drama plot!
Incorrect date/time format, please use one of these:
End time cannot be earlier than start time.
That's like eating dessert before the main course lah!
Make sure both dates have proper timing, or end time is after start time!
The file is corrupted lah, did a cat walk over the keyboard when you are saving the file?
* Exception thrown when file content is invalid, malformed, or cannot be processed.
* This exception is typically thrown during file loading operations when:

*
  • Required fields are missing from the file content

*
  • Input contains unknown task types or invalid content
* Enumeration of specific file content error types.
INVALID_JSON_FORMAT("File structure is invalid, loading failed."),
INVALID_INPUT("Unknown task type or invalid content.");
* Custom exception for date/time parsing failures with detailed error classification.

* converting itself to appropriate {@link ErrorMessage} objects.
public InvalidDateTimeException(ErrorType type, String input, Throwable cause) {

* from the error type to an appropriate standardized error message.
* @return an {@link ErrorMessage} containing a formatted error for display to end users
* Enumeration of possible filter error types with associated context messages.
* Each error type provides a specific context message that describes the nature
TOO_MANY_FILTERS("Too many criteria, maximum 3 - you think this is buffet?"),
* Custom exception for task format validation failures in MeeBot.
* Provides detailed categorization of task formatting errors by
* converting itself to appropriate {@link ErrorMessage} objects.
* Converts exception to a user-friendly error message. The returned message is mapped
* from the error type to an appropriate standardized error message.
* @return an {@link ErrorMessage} containing a formatted error for display to end users
* Enumeration of task format parsing error types.
* Each type represents a distinct category of parsing failure.
Deadline needs a description and '/by' date.
Event needs a description, '/from' start and '/to' end.
Try creating a Deadline or Event instead?
Repeating events need '/repeat' interval and count.
* Factory method to create an InvalidTaskFormatException of this error type.
* This provides a convenient way to create exceptions without explicitly
* passing the error type to the constructor.
* @return a new InvalidTaskFormatException configured with this error type
* Exception thrown when task operations encounter invalid states, inputs, or conditions.
* This exception extends {@link MeeBotException} and categorizes task-related operation
* failures into specific types by converting itself to appropriate {@link ErrorMessage} objects.
* Converts this exception to an appropriate ErrorMessage for user display.
* This method maps the error type to a formatted error message using the
* provided inputs. The specific message format depends on the error type
* and is defined in the {@link ErrorMessage} class constants.
* @return an {@link ErrorMessage} containing a formatted error for display to end users
* Enumeration of possible task operation error types.
* Each error type represents a different category of task operation failure,
* allowing for specific error handling and appropriate user feedback.
* Abstract base class for all MeeBot-specific exceptions.
* Provides a consistent exception hierarchy and standardizes error message handling.

*

All MeeBot exceptions must extend this class and implement the
* {@link #toErrorMessage()} method to provide user-friendly error messages
* that can be displayed in the user interface.

*

This class extends {@link Exception}, making it a checked exception that
* must be explicitly handled or declared in method signatures.
public abstract class MeeBotException extends Exception {
* Message displaying filtered task results with 1-based numbering and filter criteria summary.
* Generates formatted message showing filter criteria and numbered task results.
* If no tasks match the criteria, returns a helpful message explaining possible
* reasons. Otherwise, displays the filter criteria followed by a numbered list
* @return formatted message with filter summary and task list, or empty result
This could mean: (1) no matching tasks, or (2) your filter values are incorrect.
* Static farewell message displayed when the application exits.
* Generates formatted help documentation for available commands in the application.
* This class provides two modes of help display:

*
  • Overview mode: Summary of all available commands with brief descriptions.
* Invoked by {@link HelpCmd} when user requests general help.

*
  • Detail mode: Comprehensive usage information for a specific command.
* Invoked by individual command classes when user types a command keyword without arguments.
* The overview mode automatically excludes the HELP command itself to prevent recursion.
* All help documentations are retrieved from {@link CommandDocs}.
* Creates a help message displaying an overview of all available commands.
* The resulting help message will show a formatted list of all commands
* (excluding HELP) with their brief descriptions. Commands are aligned in
* @param commands array of all available command types to display
* Creates a help message displaying detailed information for a specific command.
* The resulting help message will show comprehensive documentation for the
* specified command, including usage syntax, parameter descriptions, and examples.
* @param cmd the specific command type to show detailed help for
StringBuilder content = new StringBuilder("Here's what mee can do for you:\n");
Tip: Type the command keyword (e.g. event, delete) to get the detailed usage and examples.
String content = "\uD83C\uDD98 Unlike IKEA instructions, this help actually makes sense.\n";

StringBuilder content = new StringBuilder("Here's your current mee-x of responsibilities:\n");

* @param results  filtered task list (may be empty); this list is copied defensively

Ready to mee-t your needs today!
Type 'help' to find out what can mee stir up for you today.
Type 'list' to see your tasks, or 'help' for options.
The other %d... well, they had their own vision.
See '%s' for tasks that did not make it, or type 'list' to see your tasks.
* Central processor for parsing and routing user commands into executable {@link Command} objects.
* This class serves as the main entry point for command processing, handling the conversion
* from raw user input strings to properly configured command instances. It implements a
* clean separation between input parsing and command execution.

*
  • Parse raw user input into command keywords and arguments
* @implNote This class is marked final as it represents a complete implementation
*         that should not be extended. Command-specific logic belongs in the individual
this.taskManager = Objects.requireNonNull(taskManager, "Task Manager must not be null");
* Splits user input on first whitespace to separate command keyword from arguments,
* then delegates to {@link CommandType} for command instantiation.
* @return {@link Command} object ready to execute, or {@link ErrorMessage} if parsing fails
* @apiNote The returned command is guaranteed to be non-null and executable.
* Command for adding deadline tasks to the task manager.
* Delegates task creation to {@link DeadlineCreator}, which handles parsing
* of deadline-specific input format and validation.
public final class AddDeadlineCmd extends AddTaskCmd {
* Command for adding event tasks to the task manager.
* Delegates task creation to {@link EventCreator}, which handles parsing
* of event-specific input format and validation.
public final class AddEventCmd extends AddTaskCmd {
* This command delegates task creation to a {@link TaskCreator} implementation,
* allowing different subclasses to handle different task types (e.g., todos, deadlines, events)
* with their own specific input formats and validation rules.
* Subclasses should provide a concrete {@link TaskCreator} that defines how to parse
* the command arguments and construct the appropriate task type.
public abstract class AddTaskCmd extends BaseTaskCommand {
protected AddTaskCmd(TaskManager taskManager, String args, TaskCreator creator) {
this.creator = Objects.requireNonNull(creator, "creator must not be null");
* Executes the task creation command by parsing the user input, creating a task,
* and adding it to the {@link TaskManager}.
* The specific input format and task type are determined by the {@link TaskCreator}
* @throws InvalidTaskFormatException    if the input format is invalid
* @throws InvalidDateTimeException      if the date/time cannot be parsed
* @throws InvalidTaskOperationException if the task creation fails
* @implNote Captures task manager's sorted state before modification to provide
assert args != null : "Arguments must not be null";
* Command to add a {@link TodoTask} for activities that need to be completed but
* have no specific timing requirements. Delegates task creation to {@link TodoCreator}.
public final class AddTodoCmd extends AddTaskCmd {
* Base class for commands that operate on tasks.
* Provides common dependency injection for {@link TaskManager} access and command
* arguments handling. This class implements a template method pattern where the
* {@link #execute()} method defines the execution flow, while subclasses provide
public abstract class BaseTaskCommand implements Command {
this.taskManager = Objects.requireNonNull(taskManager, "TaskManager must not be null");
* Executes the command following a standardized validation and error handling flow.
* This method ensures consistent behavior across all task commands by:
* @return a {@link Message} representing the command result, which may be a
* Determines whether this command requires a non-empty task list to execute.
* The default implementation returns {@code true}, which is appropriate for
* most commands that operate on existing tasks. Subclasses that can operate
* on empty lists (i.e., add commands) should override this to return {@code false}.
* @return {@code true} if the task list must be non-empty before execution,
* This method is called by {@link #execute()} after all validation checks
* have passed. Subclasses should implement their core functionality here
* without worrying about common validation or error handling concerns.
* @return a {@link Message} representing the command's execution result
* @throws MeeBotException if command execution fails due to invalid input
protected abstract Message executes() throws MeeBotException;
* Returns the command type that this command represents.
* Subclasses must implement this to identify their specific command type
* for help text generation and command routing.
* Interface for executable user commands. All commands follow the Command pattern,
* encapsulating a request as an object and providing a uniform interface for execution.

*
  • Return a user-friendly {@link Message} describing the result

*
  • Handle errors gracefully by returning {@link ErrorMessage} instances
* Indicates whether this command should terminate the application session.
* @return {@code false} by default. Only {@link ExitCmd} should return {@code true}.
* Enumeration defining all available commands and factory methods.
* This enum serves as a central registry for command instantiation. It provides the core
* command routing mechanism while keeping documentation concerns separated in {@link CommandDocs}.
MARK("mark", (tm, args) -> new UpdateTaskStatusCmd(tm, args, true)),
UNMARK("unmark", (tm, args) -> new UpdateTaskStatusCmd(tm, args, false));
private final BiFunction<TaskManager, String, Command> cmdFactory;
CommandType(String keyword, BiFunction<TaskManager, String, Command> cmdFactory) {
* Looks up a CommandType by keyword and perform case-insensitive matching.
* @param keyword the user input command to look up
* @return matching {@code CommandType} if found or {@code null} if no match exists
* @apiNote Returns null rather than throwing exceptions to support graceful
*         error handling in the command processing pipeline.
* Factory method to create appropriate Command instance.
* @param tm   the task manager for command execution
public Command createCommand(TaskManager tm, String args) {
* Command to remove a task from the task list by its index number.
* The index number refers to the task's position in the currently displayed list,
* which may vary depending on the active sort order. The task is identified
* by its position at the time this command executes, not by any permanent ID.
* Validates user input and removes the specified task from the list.
* @return {@link TaskDeletedMessage} containing the deleted task and updated list size
* @throws InvalidTaskOperationException if the task index is invalid or out of bounds
assert args != null : "Arguments must not be null";
* Command to terminate the application session with goodbye message.
* Signals that the application should terminate after this command.
* Command to filter tasks based on specified criteria (task type, completion status, date).
* This command allows users to retrieve tasks that match one or more filter conditions.
* All specified criteria are combined using logical AND, meaning tasks must satisfy
* all conditions to be included in the results.

*
  • At least one filter criterion must be provided

*
  • Maximum of 3 filter criteria can be applied simultaneously
*     <li>Multiple criteria are combined using logical AND. Example:
* {@code task:todo & done:true} returns only Todo task that are completed
*     <li>Conflicting criteria (e.g. {@code task:todo & task:event}) will return empty results
* since no task can satisfy contradictory conditions
* Builds a filtered message containing tasks that match the specified criteria.
* This method parses the filter arguments into predicates, applies them to the master task list,
* and materialize recurring task to specific instance if a date filter is present.
* @return {@link FilteredListMessage} containing tasks matching all criteria
* @throws InvalidFilterException   if the filter syntax is invalid or unsupported
* @throws InvalidDateTimeException if a date filter contains an invalid date format
public Message executes() throws InvalidFilterException, InvalidDateTimeException {
assert args != null : "Arguments must not be null";
* Expands recurring tasks to specific instances for the filtered date.
* If the filter arguments contain a date criterion, this method creates
* specific task instances for that date from any recurring tasks in the
* filtered list. If no date filter is present, the original filtered list is returned.
* @param filteredList the list of tasks after applying filter predicates
* @param args         the filter criteria string, potentially containing a date filter
* @return a list with recurring tasks expanded to specific date instances,
*         or the original list if no date filter is present
* @throws InvalidDateTimeException if the date filter contains an invalid date format
private List<ReadOnlyTask> expandRecurringTasks(List<ReadOnlyTask> filteredList, String args)
* Command to display help instructions for all commands in MeeBot.
* Command to display all tasks in MeeBot.
* Command to search for tasks by keywords in their descriptions.
* This command performs a case-insensitive, partial-match search across task descriptions.
* Multiple keywords are combined using OR logic, meaning a task matches if its description

*
  • OR logic: Multiple keywords match if any keyword is found
* Search for tasks by extracting keywords from user input and retrieving
* @return {@link SearchResultMessage} containing tasks matching any of the search terms
* @throws InvalidTaskFormatException if the search query format is invalid
assert args != null : "Arguments must not be null";
* Command to sort the task list by a specified criterion.
* Sorting operations are stable and the sorted order persists across the session
* until the list is modified by operations like adding or marking tasks.
* New tasks are always inserted at the bottom of the list, so a new sort command
* must be executed to maintain the desired ordering after adding tasks.

*
  • {@code /by date} - sorts by first date in chronological order (tasks without dates appear last).

*
  • {@code /by status} - sorts by completion status (incomplete tasks first).
* Sorts task based on provided criteria and returns sorted list.
* @return {@link ListTaskMessage} containing the sorted task list
* @throws InvalidTaskFormatException if the sort criterion is invalid
assert args != null : "Arguments must not be null";
* Command to update the completion status of a task by its index number.
* This command toggles a task's completion state between done and not done,
* depending on the {@code markDone} parameter provided during construction.
* The index number refers to the task's position in the currently displayed list,
* which may vary depending on the active sort order. The task is identified
* by its position at the time this command executes, not by any permanent ID.
public UpdateTaskStatusCmd(TaskManager taskManager, String args, boolean markDone) {
* Validates input, task existence, checks current state to prevent redundant
* operations, and updates the completion status of the specified task.
* @return {@link TaskMarkedMessage} on successful mark done, or
* @throws InvalidTaskOperationException if the task index is invalid, out of bounds
assert args != null : "Arguments must not be null";
* Utility class for parsing recurrence patterns from different input sources.
* This class provides static methods to convert string representations and
* Parses a string representation of recurrence from user command input.
* @param anchorDate the reference date for calculating date of last recurrence
* @param errorType  the error type to use when creating exceptions for malformed input
* @return a {@link Recurrence} object representing the parsed recurrence pattern
* @throws InvalidTaskFormatException    if the input format is invalid (wrong number of tokens,
*                                       invalid recurrence type, or invalid frequency)
* @throws InvalidTaskOperationException if the frequency cannot be parsed as an integer
assert freq > 0 : "Recurrence frequency must be positive";
return new Recurrence(type, freq, anchorDate, null);
// could be invalid enum or invalid count from Recurrence constructor
* Parses a recurrence pattern from a JSON object representation.
* The JSON object must contain a "recurrence" field with nested "type" and "count" properties.
* @param obj        the JSON object containing recurrence data
* @param anchorDate the reference date for calculating date of last recurrence
* @return a {@link Recurrence} object representing the parsed pattern
* @throws FileContentException if the JSON structure is invalid, required fields are missing,
*                              the recurrence type is unrecognized, or the count cannot be parsed as an integer
assert freq >= 0 : "Recurrence count must be non-negative";
* Utility class providing static utility methods for tokenizing and parsing
* Tokenizes a string into an array of tokens using the specified regex pattern.
* Validates that the input string matches the expected pattern and contains
* the required number of groups. Each captured token is trimmed of whitespace
* @param args          the input string to tokenize (must not be null or blank)
* @param pattern       the regex pattern for tokenization
* @param requiredToken the expected number of tokens to extract
* @param errorType     the error type to throw if tokenization fails
* @return an array of trimmed, non-empty tokens
* @throws InvalidTaskFormatException if the input is null/blank, doesn't match
*                                    the pattern, has wrong number of groups, or contains empty tokens
public static String[] tokenize(String args, Pattern pattern,
assert requiredToken > 0 : "requiredToken must be greater than 0";
Matcher matcher, int requiredToken, ErrorType errorType)
* Utility class for converting string arguments into task filter {@link Predicate}
* objects that can be used to filter task collections.

*
  • date: Filters by date (matches any task with the specified date)

*

Thread Safety: This class is thread-safe as it contains only static methods
* Parses filter argument string into a combined predicate. All predicates are combined
* using logical AND, meaning tasks must satisfy ALL criteria to pass the filter.
* @param args filter criteria string with ampersands(&) delimited filters
* @return combined predicate that applies all filters with AND logic
* @throws InvalidFilterException   if filter format is invalid or too many filters are provided
* @throws InvalidDateTimeException if date filter contains invalid date format
assert predicates.stream().allMatch(Objects::nonNull) : "Predicates must not contain null entries";
// Chain all predicates with AND logic
* Parses a single filter token (key:value pair) into a task predicate.
* Both key and value must be non-empty.
* @return predicate for the specified filter criteria
* @throws InvalidFilterException   if token format is invalid (wrong format, empty key/value)
* @throws InvalidDateTimeException if date filter contains invalid date format
* Factory for creating appropriate predicate based on filter key and value.
* Each predicate type has specific validation and matching logic appropriate for its data type.
* Implementation Note: Date filtering ignores time components and matches
* @return predicate that matches the specified criteria
* @throws InvalidFilterException   for unknown keys or invalid values

// Test: within recurrence period but not an occurrence
@DisplayName("Monthly recurring event should shift full interval across months")

// Test: within recurrence period but not an occurrence

Recurrence r = new Recurrence(RecurrenceType.YEARLY, 5, anchor, null);
